awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Wireless sensors for obesity and associated chronic diseases
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to offer a low cost, personal device to fight obesity and its related chronic associated conditions by tracking metabolic rate. This is particularly important as modern society as a whole adopts a sedentary lifestyle. There is clear correlation between overweight and increased risks of many diseases, such as cardiovascular disease, diabetes, cancers, metabolic syndrome and high blood pressure, and over 140 million people in the US alone are overweight or obese.


The proposed project tackles this challenge by providing a tool that can track metabolic rate (to determine energy used and amount of food required), anaerobic threshold, and peak oxygen consumption rate (to optimize amount and types of activities). Such a tool has not been available until now due to multiple technical challenges that require sensitive and miniaturized sensors for detection of carbon dioxide and oxygen concentrations in breath with sub-second resolution and <1% accuracy, and would also require measurement of breath flow rate over a wide dynamic range under minimal flow resistance. To address these challenges, first, chemical sensors based on a hierarchical sensing material approach will be developed. This approach organizes sensing materials at different length scales, from nm to mm, into hierarchical structures to achieve fast and selective detection of the analytes. Second, to measure breath flow rate, a novel low-cost, power-free acoustic sensor will be developed, which converts breath into an acoustic signal that can be detected and analyzed with the built-in microphone of a cell phone. Finally, a prototype device will be calibrated and validation to demonstrate its functionality against expensive, bulky stand-alone gold standard reference methods.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit:

This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project is to develop a personal device which can help fight problems such as obesity, fatigue, diabetes management, and other chronic conditions associated with overweight. The new technology offers recommendation on how much food one should consume or how much exercise one needs to accomplish their weight goals. In addition, it helps optimize exercise regimen to maximum efficiency. These features were made possible through the tracking of metabolic rate, anaerobic threshold, heart rate and peak oxygen consumption rate which has not been created before due to multiple technical challenges. Such a device would require sensitive and miniaturized sensors for detection of carbon dioxide and oxygen concentrations in breath with fast time-resolution and better than 1% accuracy, and would also require measurement of breath flow rate over a wide dynamic range under minimal flow resistance. TF Health Co. and collaborators at the Center for Bioelectronics and Biosensors, Biodesign Institute at ASU have prepared innovative solutions to address these challenges. For example, in order to simultaneously detect carbon dioxide and oxygen concentrations in breath, chemical sensors based on a hierarchical sensing material approach and low cost wet electrochemistry will be developed. The hierarchical approach organizes sensing materials at different length scales, from nanometer to millimeter, into hierarchical structures to achieve fast and selective detection of the analytes; while the electrochemical approach combines conventional electrochemistry with micron-thick electrolyte together with innovative fluidic engineering for fast and reproducible results. To measure breath flow rate, a low backpressure thermal based flow sensor has been developed, which provides robust, accurate, and fast measurements under minimal backpressure.

Broader Impacts:

Obesity and overweight affect over 140 million in the U.S. alone and many millions more around the world. The project addresses this fast and growing market by providing a personal device for evidence-based weight and fitness management that can track key physiological parameters, which, currently, is possible only with expensive/bulky equipment. The present project: 1) translates traditional expensive and bulky metabolic carts and sports physiology equipment from the research lab and into the palms of users; 2) provided an effective tool to empower individuals who wish to achieve and maintain a healthy weight and fitness level, and motivate users to incorporate balanced diet and physical activity into their lifestyle through scientific evidence, and; 3) established the hierarchical and electrochemical sensing platforms that will also be able to capture other biomarkers for other health diagnostic purposes.

TF Health Co. is an ASU spin-off company, and this project further involved ASU faculty and students (via a sub-contract), working together with researchers at TF Health. The project exposed students with significant entrepreneurial experience and learned how research at a University lab is translated into versatile real-world solutions, and how to incorporate this hands-on training in their future career endeavors.

There has been an opportunity for us to introduce our technologies in a science fair where we showed and allowed attendees to try our first generation of the technology. In addition, during the fair, we had the opportunity to talk to people and introduce them to what we are working on in this NSF project,  interviewed them about their experience with weight loss, their opinions and willingness to invest on our proposed technologies. The participants were from a very diverse background. From children to retirees, youths to parents. Through our demonstration of the application of science, we can observe that some of the...
